captions.text: Giant panda cub, Yuan Zai, is now walking on her own
She may not be steady yet
but every time the keepers put her back in the den, she crawls right out
Yuan Zai is very curious about any surrounding sound or movement
and loves to explore
Yuan Zai is a very determined panda bear. Once she locks down a target, she immediately moves toward it
What are you looking for, Yuan Zai?
Is it the bucket? the zoo keeper? or the broom?
Sometimes she slips, but she stands up right away
She walks over to the keeper to see what's up
Do you think she's shadowing or supervising him?
After the room is cleaned
Our keepers will have Yuan Yuan come back to have breakfast here
Yuan Zai hears the sound of rustling leaves from the other room
and runs over to check it out
(Yuan Zai: What is this sound?)
Yuan Zai stops to take a short break
and marches on!
Yuan Zai finds mommy by following the sound!
Yuan Yuan is calmly eating her breakfast
Yuan Zai is not sure what to do next
and makes a few sounds
Mother panda is still enjoying her breakfast
Yuan Zai checks out her surroundings
Yuan Yuan finally finishes her breakfast
and walks past Yuan Zai
She quickly patrols the other room before coming back for Yuan Zai
She wants to bring Yuan Zai to bed
Since Yuan Zai is now a big baby
Yuan Yuan has to try a few different angle
before dragging Yuan Zai with her mouth and arms
But not without a mini break in the middle of the journey
Yuan Yuan switches over to the other side and drags on
Yuan Zai seems reluctant to go with her mom
Eventually Yuan Yuan prevails!
Through the mirror you can see Yuan Yuan in the corner
is lovingly holding Yuan Zai
Yuan Yuan is such a kind mother!

title: 圓圓的育兒之道 Giant Panda Yuan Yuan's Parenting (English Subtitle Available)

comments.text:
According to what I know. There are ~1600 Pandas in the wild that breeds by 
themselves naturally. And ~300 pandas in captive, human intervention helps 
them breed with a higher successful rate and in bigger number. And Chinese 
government already tried to release some of the captive grown up pandas 
back to the wild. But they still need more experience in helping the pandas 
to return to the wild. And according to some report, the new born baby is 
susceptible to disease. Human intervention ensure every baby grew up to 
adult.﻿

comments.author: Wolfcat Wildcat

comments.text:
Well yes, as far as I know, there's inner enclosures for both Tuantuan (the 
male panda in Taipei Zoo) and Yuanyuan (mother)/Yuanzai (baby). The video 
is Yuanyuan/Yuanzai's inner enclosure. They lead to outdoor (private) 
gardens (sometimes when the temperature/weather is fine the keepers will 
bring Yuanzai out to play for a while before going to the exhibition ground 
since she's now big enough.) Then there's 1 outdoor exhibition area and 2 
indoor exhibition areas  with which the panda family take turns to be in.

comments.author: djbethell

comments.text:
+WAY I learned just now that pandas have a political purpose.  Sometimes 
they're involved with trade relations between the PRC and Taiwan; such was 
the case for Yuan Zai's parents.  In fact, I think Yuan Zai's grandmother 
is "Hua Mei", which roughly means "China/USA"....though, Hua Mei is from 
Tuan Tuan's side, not Yuan Yuan (the mother).

Anyway, this is the reality of Animalia sometimes.  If we let some animals 
just roam free, they may end up dead.  Pandas are an endangered species, 
and I read there's only over a thousand left on Earth.  Broadly speaking, 
it's not our place to interfere with Animalia, but sometimes there comes a 
circumstance where it is necessary to help animals, because harm might be 
inevitable towards them in the long run.  That's something a lot of people 
don't seem to understand.  Instead they think all animals should be 
released from zoos and left to "roam free", not knowing they might end up 
dead, either by Nature itself or by poachers and such.

+Mikhael37
Without meaning to come across as sarcastic, flippant or mean, it sounds to 
me like they might just possibly have chosen to become extinct (and would

comments.author: djbethell

comments.text:
+djbethell The BBC documentary "Panda Makers" features the relocation of 
one panda from the US to China and explains all what I said. You can also 
read the Wikipedia article on giant pandas or search on Google for China's 
"Panda Diplomacy". You were right, it's terrible that we have to confine 
them in cages, but this is the least of their problems. They're about to go 
extinct because not only are they highly selective of their mating 
partners, they have a window in which to reproduce of only two days every 
year. Having said that, they seem to be enjoying their life on the reserves 
and in zoos. Personally, I wish I was a panda living on one of these zoos 
or reserves, and people were actively trying to bring me the best food that 
I like (Pizza) and hot chicks to mate with so that I won't become extinct
comments.author: Mikhael37

comments.text:
+Mikhael37 Please inform me about where you have got all this info. Links 
would be incredibly valuable!
comments.author: djbethell

comments.text:
+djbethell pandas are an endangered species and right now many are living 
in reserves and zoos to help with their breeding, when little Yuan Zai 
turns 4, it will be sent to one of the reserves in China to participate in 
the research meant to save the species. It will be a traumatic experience, 
the same as with other pandas sent back from dozens of zoos around the 
world. (They do get used to the zoos and love it there, and when sent back 
to China to live in reserves, they show signs of depression for months). 
But it's for the greater good: saving pandas from extinction. In the end 
it's a choice between "concrete, bars, and prisons" and extinction
comments.author: Mikhael37

comments.text: People who hate concrete, bars and prisons, (sorry, I meant Zoos).

comments.text:
"" 現在的「圓仔」活動力十足，當保育員在清掃牠跟媽媽的房間時，「圓仔」會朝著移動的東 
­西或聲音傳來的方向努力前進，而不乖乖地待在產房裡，時而追著掃把或跟著塑膠桶還有保­育員。每當保育員將「圓仔」放回竹床，沒多久牠就會走出來到處亂跑，「圓圓」這時候正­在另一端開心地吃著竹葉，發出了沙沙聲；「圓仔」循著聲音來源前進找到媽媽，但媽媽並­未立即過去抱起牠，而仍淡定的吃著竹葉。突然「圓圓」好像想到了什麼，繞到「圓仔」身­邊，嘗試各種方式想將「圓仔」叼起帶回竹床，像是媽媽教導孩子不要到處亂跑一樣；但因­為「圓仔」現在已經是個大寶寶了，所以「圓圓」最後用半叼半拖的方式才將「圓仔」帶回­去。「圓仔」前些日子還不會走路時，總是乖乖地被媽媽「圓圓」叼著走；但現在牠已經會­趴趴走了，所以有時候會看到「圓仔」被媽媽叼著時，仍揮舞著四肢或努力撐著，像是不想­乖乖就範的頑皮孩一樣。「圓圓」漸漸摸索出一套自己的育兒方式，且會隨著寶寶的成長改­變；會適時的教導「圓仔」，但當「圓仔」肚子餓或要便便時，也會溫柔慈愛的將牠抱起來­擁入懷中，讓「圓仔」安心的喝ㄋㄟㄋㄟ。""

comments.author: tickyul

comments.text:
To everyone complaining about the conditions these animals live in:
 If you use a cell phone, drive a car, have electricity in your home, buy 
food from grocery stores, have a natural gas or propane line connected 
to your home, have carpet, vinyl, plastic or any other man made materials 
in your home, then you are the reason why they live in these conditions, 
you are why they have no wild habitat left to live in. If not for the Zoos 
then many species would already be extinct.
 Whales were hunted to near extinction because people wanted them 
slaughtered for oil to burn so they could have light in their homes... Same 
thing(in principal) still happening 300 years later.
 Wild habitats are destroyed so that consumers can have more 
worthless stuff and nothing else, so before you start crying about 
corporations and governments look at yourself and see if you are a part of 
the chain.
 We the people are what enables them to make profit from claiming  jungle 
for farmland, to build mines, oil fields, roads, create pollution, build 
factories, over harvest natural resources, and on and on.
 Nature is a delicate complex web, and the more we partake in technology 
the more destruction we cause. The good news is that humans aren't powerful 
enough to destroy the Earth, only powerful enough to make it inhospitable 
to us, nature will reach its breaking point, correct the problem, shake us 
silly humans off and go on without us.
 We do not own the Earth, it owns us, if you live against nature you will 
lose.
  ﻿
comments.author: John Lacy

comments.text:
+djbethell Over simplistic? Well, it is a YT post not a round table 
discussion...there's only so much space available for a single post.
 But, the bottom line is that turning jungle into farmland causes 
desertification, pumping billions and billions of gallons of oil out of 
the earth and burning it in the atmosphere causes too many disturbances to 
nature to list here, I can go on and on all day with this stuff.
 The results of consumerism are changing the planet before your very eyes 
yet you and some other people here claim that we don't impact nature, we 
can just do whatever we like and there are no reactions to our actions its 
always some other explanation, like your account of the problem 
with pandas. You think their gene pool got low just because they lost 
interest in sex, and it had nothing to do with deforestation and the 
removal their ecological niche, eh? You may have stated the reason why 
pandas are close to extinction you just forgot to include the part about 
how it got to be that way. Kind of like saying someone who got shot really 
died from bleeding to death.
 Isn't it ironic that you're post was so oversimplified?
comments.author: John Lacy

comments.text:
A rather over simplistic view there John Lacy. It's got nothing to do with 
the panda's pretty low gene pool at all, eh?
